The missile knows where it is at all times. It knows this because it knows where it isn't. By subtracting where it is from where it isn't, or where it isn't from where it is - whichever is greater - it obtains a difference or deviation. The guidance subsystem uses deviations to generate corrective commands to drive the missile from a position where it is to a position where it isn't, and arriving at a position that it wasn't, it now is. Consequently, the position where it is is now the position that it wasn't, and if follows that the position that it was is now the position that it isn't. In the event that the position that it is in is not the position that it wasn't, the system has acquired a variation. The variation being the difference between where the missile is and where it wasn't. If variation is considered to be a significant factor, it too may be corrected by the GEA. However, the missile must also know where it was. The missile guidance computer scenario works as follows: Because a variation has modified some of the information that the missile has obtained, it is not sure just where it is. However, it is sure where it isn't, within reason, and it know where it was. It now subtracts where it should be from where it wasn't, or vice versa. And by differentiating this from the algebraic sum of where it shouldn't be and where it was, it is able to obtain the deviation and its variation, which is called error.

I've visited the TMM twice, the last time the same year you made this video. My first job out of school was ground support for an Air Force reconnaissance satellite that launched on a Titan IIIB, so I was more than a little familiar with the Titan's technology. When I was able to answer some of the other visitors' questions better than he could, the docent asked if was local since he wanted to hire me!

BTW, for anyone wondering why the "Butterfly Valve" has such a lightweight sounding name for something that causes Armageddon, it has to do with the propellants used. They were hypergolic, meaning that no ignition system was needed since they explode spontaneously on contact. The propellants were controlled by butterfly valves (like the kind in your car's intake), both operated by a common actuator. In this way, you could be sure that either both propellants would start together or neither would flow. It also made the failsafe lockout mentioned easier to do since you only had to control one. Disabling the lockout withdrew the pin preventing motion of the butterfly valves, thus enabling the launch.

One neat thing that didn't get mentioned is there are four nozzles connected to a 100,000 gallon water tank that blasts water into the missile exhaust stream when the engines fire, by robbing the exhaust of energy by steam conversion it reduces the massive noise of the engine during lift off. The water system with those acoustic panels in the silo keep the missile from coming apart by the roar of its engine

The titan missile museum Channel has quite a few interesting videos.  The butterfly valve system was also hardwired to their air force base, jacking around with it would set off an alarm at the base and you would quickly be getting a call from them.  The tries counter yeah gave you six chances for the life of the system to get the code right, otherwise it kicks the bucket on the 7th try and you are probably kaput in the air force.  Trying to break into the lock of the valve itself would cause an explosive charge to jam the locking pin in place permanently and it would never open.  One o the guys who worked on the valves said they had to wait for a 24 hour timer to run out to even service that valve or it would blow and jam shut

The missile knows where it is at all times.
It knows this because it knows where it isn't.
By subtracting where it is from where it isn't,
Or where it isn't from where it is,
whichever is greater,
It obtains a difference, or, 'deviation'.
The guidance subsystem uses deviations to generate corrective commands
To drive the missile from a position where it is to a position where it isn't,
And arriving at a position where is wasn't it now is.
Consequently the position where it is is now the position that it wasn't,
And it follows that the position that it was is now the position that it isn't.

In the event that the position that it is in is not the position that it wasn't,
The system has acquired a variation,
The variation being the difference being between where the missile is and where it wasn't.
If variation is considered to be a significant factor, it too may be corrected by the GEA,
However, the missile must also know where it was.
The missile guidance computer scenario works as follows:
Because a variation has modified some of the information the missile has obtained,
It is not sure just where it is,
However, it is sure where it isn't... within reason,
And it knows where it was.
It now subtracts where it should be from where it wasn't, or vice versa.
And by differentiating this from the algebraic sum of where it shouldn't be and where it was,
It is able to obtain the deviation and its variation, which is called error.

4:02 Ah, yes. The butterfly valve lock. As far as I'm concerned, that's the most important safety feature on the whole site to prevent unauthorized or unintentional launches.

The first stage engine has two thrust chambers, and both thrust chambers have two feed lines. One feed line is for fuel, and the other feed line is for the oxidizer. All four of those lines are equipped with butterfly valves, and all four of those butterfly valves need to be open for that missile to fly.

The first thrust chamber's oxidizer feed line butterfly valve has a lock on it.

In order to unlock it, you need to enter a secret code that came in with the 35-character coded launch order that you received. It's the first and only time that you EVER knew what that code was. There's six thumbwheels, and sixteen characters on each one. So that's 16^6, which means there are slightly less than 16 million 800 thousand possible combinations, and only one works. Now those sound like pretty good odds, right?

Well, the Air Force didn't like taking any chances, evidenced by the fact that they put in a tries counter.

In order to prevent any kind of tampering, they put in a lifetime-spanning tries counter. You could only get the combination wrong six times. This tries counter NEVER reset. On the seventh attempt, even if you got it right, the entire computer system was programmed to commit an electronic suicide. After that, it would take at least two hours with many technicians to bring the computer system back to an active status, and they would have to reset the mechanically-operating tries counter manually.

If that ever happened while you were on duty as commander? Well... Suffice it to say that you have NOT enhanced your military career.

Good Job been to the Titan Missle Museum a couple times but did not get this walk through of what a actual launch would be like. But on my first trip they told a interesting story about the guys working the silo and one of the drills was targeting or changing the target to a manual disignated target. Those of us old enough to remember paper punch cards well they used a paper punch tape for those early computers. The story was that the incoming crew worked through their check list and checked the equipment one check was where was the missle aimed at now? The last crew had used Washington DC as a training model to do a manual target setup and the paper tape was still in the player. Don't know how true this is but made for a interesting story. But HIGHLY recomend visiting the Museum well worth the trip and its very quite one you get below ground level and the A/C is ON.

I once took the exact same course in Moscow, in a bunker "68 floors below ground" or so.
They even had a huge screen atop the whole aperture you sit infront when you perform the launch sequence on which you see how the missile you just launched flying into space, disassembling into the re-entry vehicles and then a sudden cut is made, showing a pretty, small town or village, in typical 60s-suburbia flavor getting completely obliterated by an REV.

Deterrence works and recent history is proof. The fact that the US is stepping out or not renewing it's nuclear arms and proliferation treaties is worrying as the world is in a very tough spot right now and it will be for the next decade at least. And this would be the good scenario, the bad one is the one where deterrence fails.

The Nuclear Triad is a bit weak in my opinion. Land based ICBM's are low on the triad, just like B-52, B-1B, and B-2 nuclear bomber bases. The problem is, their location is known. The Soviets/Russians had/have them targeted. Bombers take a little time for crews to get their gear, run to the planes, start up, taxi to the active, take off, then accelerate, and climb fast, so they can increase their distance from the base, so when it's hit, the blast wave won't knock them out of the sky. I think for dramatic purposes you could say Titan II's warhead was the most powerful ever deployed by US Strategic forces. Truth is, it was the most powerful through brute force only. Later warheads had an added lower nominal yield but were far more effective and deadly.

Technology at the time had a limit: the system wasn't as accurate as later tech warheads. Those 7 megatons were needed to ensure the warhead could be used as a counter-weapon asset, to knock out soviet nuclear silos. As the warheads couldn't be guaranteed to land near enough the targetted silo, they needed to be ourageously powerful to compensate for it, so a hit landing farther than expected would still guarantee a 100% chance of knocking out the target.

And that's because Titan II wasn't a deterrent for MAD. It wasn't the US strategic weapon of choice to counter-attack after the enemy had delivered a first strike. Those would've been SAC's strategic bomber fleet and short/medium range ballistic missiles (such as Jupiter first, then Pershing, etc) and (later on) the US Navy first generation of SSBN and SLBMs (Poseidon). But not Titan II.

Titan II was a true first-strike capable delivery vehicle and it's job was that of a first-strike delivery vector. Not deterrance. First strike. It was the weapon that would be used to attack first, and it's job was to destroy as many soviet silos as they could to, precisely, deny the soviets the ability to strike back in the very way the man in the video says Titan would do if the US was attacked.

And Titan II's warhead was so powerful because of the job it had to do. Later advancements on inertial navigation, missile guidance, and MIRV technology ensured circular error probabilities of less than a couple hundred meters, more than close enough to guarantee silo destructions with far less nominal yields.
At that stage multi-megaton warheads were not needed anymore and instead were substituted in the next generation of ICBMs (the Minuteman missile and later on the MX) by payloads with several independent reentry warheads with yields in the area of 500kt (14 times lower than the 7MT in Titan II) - and they still were not only more efficient at their job of counter-weapon (thanks to their larger precission) but allowed for each missile to attack several targets, thus multiplying the number of soviet silos that could be struck on a first attack. Meanwhile the very same advancements in guidance, navigation and accuracy turned the SSBN fleet in yet another first-strike capable force once the Trident missile was deployed.

As a further note, those missiles were NOT reprogrammable. At least not during an emergency. One of the specific purposes and targets of the MX program was to give the US a missile fleet which targets could be reprogrammed easily (we're talking that with MX they were aiming to achieve in the range of maybe half a day to reprogram the whole missile fleet target selection, and that was in the 80s. Titan II was 60s tech). Titan II could take days (if not weeks) to be rewired for a different target. You couldn't send it to any other place than it's intended target on the fly on a whim. Certainly not once enemy ICBMs had been detected incoming. At that point you just launched them at their designated targets, nd their targets weren't soviet cities. They were soviet silos. Furthening the proof that Titan II was a first strike vector, not a "deterrance" asset.

Later on Minuteman allowed for each missile to have a hard-wired selection of maybe half a dozen several targets. You could swap from one to another much faster, but still couldn't be done "on the fly" (meaning, once an incoming attack was detected, at which point you only had maybe 30 minutes to launch back before being struck). Still not enough to be used as deterrant: the whole US Minuteman ICBM force was targetted at soviet silos, not cities, and was as much a first strike asset as Titan had been before it.

That missile wasn't a counterattack asset. The US ICBM force was, by design, a first strike asset. Deterrance was left for other weapons and branches of the military. I pass no judgement on it, the US needed a nuclear arsenal for that particular job and deployed that missile, the same the soviet depoyed their own first-strike nuclear delivery forces. It's an abject role as being the agressor in a nuclear war is morally repugnant...but still it was a role that needed filling at the time. The Cold War was real, the possibility of a nuclear war was VERY real, and the US needed first strike capability to remain in the race and not be left behind. Titan did fill it, as later on Minuteman, MX and Trident went on to fill it. They were necessary evils, but were evil weapons with an evil role nonetheless, not the "morally acceptable" counterstrike "we would've only used it had we been struck first" fairy tale we're told in this video. That's a plain, bold, and dirty lie.

And I don't like it. History needs to be told right, and things need to be told truthfully, even if that truth we don't like.

The point of nuclear weapons isn't peace, but keeping the authority of a state. A retaliation will have little effect on reducing the enemy nuclear arsenal before it gets delivered, it's just payback for violating a treat, a selfish act of arrogance in the face of destruction.

Nuclear weapons don't just destroy the enemy. They lay waste on the biosphere. The scale of destruction caused by a thermonuclear device is so great that the area affected would never give any significant profit in face of the challenging task of turning it into something useful to humans again.

One does not add nuclear devices to the arsenal as means of conquering. If deployed, they have the sole objective of forcing the enemy to surrender in order to not suffer further loses. In other words, they force a war that is already won to end faster. That's what happened back in WW2.

This goes by the assumption that only one side can deploy nuclear weapons, be it because they are their sole users or because the enemy has no means of using its arsenal, or that it is so small that using it will only fasten their doom.

When nations threat each other with nuclear devices, they are merely presenting a posture that says "we'll never surrender", telling that all conflicts will be settled outside their borders - with conventional weaponry - and that they would rather condemn the entire world than give on their pride.

So no, no war in the near future will ever be fought with nuclear devices. If one is deployed against an enemy that has the ability to respond, we are merely bringing the end to 99% of the multicelular life on Earth.

And that isn't an act of war, it's planetary suicide.

when I was in the USAF's Strategic Air Command, working on Minuteman III and MX missile silos the set up was entirely different. The launch control capsule was not located on site with any missile silo's. The 200 or so missile silo's assigned to F E Warren AFB that we were assigned to maintain were broken into 20 flights of 10 silos per flight. Each flight of 10 missile silos were located within the same geographic area with no two silos being within multiple miles of one another. Somewhere buried deep in the ground within each flights geographic area was the Launch Control Capsule which had support facilities topside that were manned 24/7 with a combination of personnel including the Launch Control Officers, security for the entire flight area, a cook, etc etc. The silos themselves did not have personnel on site 24/7.

From 9/66 thru 2/69 I was assigned to the 381st Strategic Missile Wing at McConnell AFB, Wichita, Kansas.  My job was maintaining the wired communications systems on the launch sites, including those speakers you heard the EWO message over, as well as the many intercom headsets used by maintenance personnel, and the various private line telephones used to control site access.  I noticed that your guide was Chuck Penson.  He has published a rather comprehensive book about the Titan II from the concept to the construction, the functionality, how various systems worked, all the way through to the decommissioning and destruction of the sites. Tons of pictures and diagrams.  A great resource for anyone interested in the most devastating weapon system ever deployed and a walk down memory lane for us old guys who proudly wore the “pocket rocket” (Missileman badge) back in the day.

Based on reading several books on this topic, I think the video is quite misleading. My understanding is that each group of Titan II silos had several launch control centers. If one center turned their keys but the others did not, there would be a short delay (a few minutes) before the missile launched. During this delay, all of the control centers would receive an alarm indicating that a launch was initiated by one of the centers. During those few minutes, any of the launch control centers could abort the launch sequence. The idea was that a normal launch would require unanimous agreement across all the launch control centers. If any of the centers were destroyed or the 2-man crew inside incapacitated, then the launch would still proceed but with a short delay. However, any surviving center could abort a launch in progress during the delay.

I was secondary support (HF/UHF radio repair) for the Titan systems in Kansas in the late '70s. Many a time I was in the command center working on equipment when a launch alert came in. We knew the alert 'Skybird, skybird..... this is SAC airborne Command Post...." With that, we knew to immediately leave the control room, normally to level 3 where our equipment racks were, until the drill was complete.
The launch process was repeated over and over and over again until these folks could do it in their sleep. I would hate to be in their shoes for the sheer responsibility, but proudly supported them knowing the reason we were all there.

It is sad today, as I ask young adults "Do you know what the Cold War was?", and got blank stares from 25 year olds.... What ever happened to history lessons in school? I guess because my era didn't spill blood it wasn't noteworthy...

I've rewatched this video several times over the years since its release and it still gives me chills. Breaking away the facade of something being so complicated and showing that it was so simple that only 2 people could hold the power to set-off the end of modern civilization. Some of you could call this a dramatization with the added effects of music, lighting, and footage; but the fact being that no matter how overly dramatic a reenacment might be, this was all that it took to start our own destruction. It reminds me of the incident that nearly happened during the Cuban Missle Crisis where a Soviet submarine was within seconds of launching a nuclear tipped torpedo, only to be talked out of it by one of the three men onboard whom all had to agree to the launch. Its almost unthinkable that as few as 2 or 3 people could have the potential to cause the deaths of potentially billions of people by just the turn of a few keys.

If you happen to be in the area, I suggest a visit to the Ronald Reagan Minuteman Missile State Historic Site, in North Dakota, USA. It's a museum, with a restored circa-1982 launch control center for one of the (now decomissioned) Minuteman missile silo fields.

From a distance, it looks like a normal ranch house - though with a strong fence around it. The upstairs is off-duty and sleeping areas, and a small control room. In the control room is an elevator, in which you can ride down to the actual control and equipment rooms, which are below ground. Interesting tour.

Yay! That's our Titan II silo museum. Star Trek: First Contact was partially filmed there. Titan I silos are massive in comparison btw. I'd love to see a complete tour of one of those (to date - only urban explorer vids have show parts of them and they were in terrible shape). I'm aware of one near DIA in Colorado that might be a candidate. The batteries to power the on-board missile system was particularly ingenious. They used gravity fed electrolytics that would be poured into the anode case when the bags holding them would be punctured. In seconds you had a charged battery ready for use - that would never leak or degrade indefinitely - keeping the battery viable - forever (because it was assembled at time-of-use). My father worked on a variant of the Titan II (he worked on 3 nuclear missile systems altogether, including a defensive interceptor or AMM). The Titan II was a single-warhead design. Later missiles including the MX were MIRV capable launching a platform that would park in orbit and scan targets for multiple secondary warhead deliveries. Megatons of fun. Finally, early astronauts riding on re-purposed nuclear missiles found their GEICOs would at orbit be 'hunting' for targets. The pilot of the spacecraft would have to override the  desire to nose-down for re-entry (until purpose-built rockets were developed for future spacecraft).

Ve  thank you .  Acoustics you say ?  August 1985 I was a visitor on Vandenburg  Air force base . The night before our host brought us down to see the Ocean after we had Dinner . The next morning  The whole place started shaking and at first I thought" my First time to California and I get an earthquake right off the bat " .   Wrong again Mark !  This went on for 2 minutes and towards 3 minutes the noise  and vibration was less .    It was the very first test fire of an Mx  Missile out of a Silo . I have spent many hours studying this era and these weapons. I have taken tours of a 'coffin launcher' and a silo based Atlas. A stark reality of these systems is that most of them would not work. In speaking with several people 'in the know', the success rate of actual pre-launch malfunction was roughly 76%... For reasons like repairs, corrosion, electrical, miss-reporting of malfunction and issues with a very complex launch readiness support system etc.

Then, if they did not explode in the silo, once clear the chance of an engine or critical flight component not working properly further diminished the chances of an accurate strike. In fact the likely hood of a failed unit falling on a friendly populated area was very real. Though technically not armed until seconds before striking, after the crash of a missile armed with typical two stage nuclear detonation components, (Fission/Fusion initiation) would cause the accident area be absolutely lethal for untold time; 100's maybe 1000's of years.

Factor in the failure of targeting and corrective telemetry (On some systems), well, you get it. All issues added together made these things as dangerous to 'us' as they were to 'them'.

Bottom line. With a documented, calculated success rate of less than 1%, this was all tremendously expensive folly that benefited ONLY the Military Industrial Complex.
But America has lost the war in Vietnam, Afghanistan, Iraq and Somalia 😄

There was a way a single person could launch. As an electrical engineer I knew the trick. But it involved killing the crew first. Then a very strong crowbar to open the launch control panel. Then you could go behind the launch control panel (not the commander's console) and add a jumper. No need for a key. Only a few of us had the schematics so it was not too bad and those of us that knew the trick never passed on to any other engineers.

Regarding the sound suppression there was also 100,000 gallons of water released just below the 1st stage engines. There were also fire valves at the top of the silo that were fed by the same reservoir as the sound suppression. Once, in one of our complexes, someone goofed and caused the fire sprays to come on (hmm, it wasn't me). It was not discovered until the new crew came on the next day. The bottom of the silo (the "W") was full of water and the missile could not be launched. The water was over the sump pumps so they could not be used to pump out the water so the missile was taken off of alert. The issue went top secret ... that didn't make HQ very happy.

I worked on this missile in the Air Force in the 1970s.  I was a Pneudraulics Tech.  Pneudraulics is a combination of Pneumatics and Hydraulics combined into one system.   I worked on the 760 ton Silo Closure door which could open in 11 to 29 seconds.  With a Pneumatically charged "accumulator reservoir" and a working pressure of 6,500 psig., the door  could open, close, and open again, all without power to the pump.  I also worked on the retractable "work platforms,"  "Blast Doors," Missile Guidance System," Blast Valves," and pneumatically charged Antennas, that would pop up out of the ground after an attack.  The missile carried either a single "9 Megaton Bomb" or 5 smaller "MIRVS."  (Multiple Independent Reentry Vehicles)   This is the same "Launch Vehicle"  (The Titan 2 Rocket) that hefted the 2 man, "Gemini Space Craft," that proceeded the "Apollo Saturn 5," Rockets that went to the moon.

I knew a guy who was a silo launch officer. He went crazy and had to retire from the service from his work. The reason being every once in a while, without any warning, his phone would ring at home and he would be ordered to the silo asap. Could be 8 o'clock at night on Christmas Eve or 3 am on a regular Tuesday. He would rush to the silo, everyone on base would be in full war mode. When he got into the launch control room the codes and pre launch sequence would be started. The guys would be brought right up to the last second before actual launch and an "abort" order would be given. He said the most mental torment would be the few minutes they would all wait in silence to receive the abort or launch order. The excercise would happen seldom enough to create the real feeling of actual war. It became too much and caused a mental break after a while. He said the most mentally horrible thing was backing out of his drive way and seeing the silhouette of his wife and kids in the front window. He knew he was never going to see them again. These silo guys were a different breed. Like the boomer sub guys.

I think this is a bit misinformative. It just shows the very last action. For a start you cannot have a fully fueled ICBM just sat in the silo 24/7. The fuel is way too volatile for that, and various factors, such as temperature, corrosion, and degradation means it is impossible. Just as it would be impossible to have a fully fueled Apollo mission sat permanently at Kennedy Space Station. The missile needs to be fueled first, which would only happen across the board in a DEFCON 1, or maybe DEFCON 2. Other than that, nearly all the continental based nuclear weapons sit unfueled. That is why a pre-emptive strike is considered a possibility, and why air launched, and submarine launched systems exist. Air launched can simply be dropped, and submarines get much closer to the target, which means rocket delivery systems are not necessary, but they use delivery systems similar to cruise missiles. So relatively few ICBM's can be launched immediately in normal day to day times. Secondly, and for similar reasons, all nuclear missiles cannot be permanently ready because of the warhead. The material required for a nuclear weapon is both unstable, and highly explosive.  There is a whole industry, a subsidiary of the nuclear energy industry, that is continuously, preparing warheads. The assembly and fitting procedure is all done last minute. Another reason why in peace time relatively few ICBM's are operational at any one time. And the reason nuclear energy industries in some countries upsets the major powers. This necesitated a huge nuclear arsenal, which alongside interception calculations, lead to a situation called overkill. Maintaining that arsenal, given the problems I have explained is also prohibitively expensive. Counter measures are a lot cheaper. Chances are very high that the civilian population would be very aware of the dangers before a nuclear exchange, it would not come as a surprise out of the blue, but most likely the conclusion of an already existing war

In sub commander has a letter written by the current Prime Minister telling them what to do: retaliate immediately, do not retaliate, do as you wish, or place them under command of an Allied Navy, in the case that the government of the United Kingdom is destroyed. How to know that it's gone? Well, supposedly one of the clues is BBC radio went off the air for a number of days, and they can't establish contacts.

Coming at this from a physical security perspective while not considering human collusion or other social attacks, from first-looks it appears this setup (the two independent locks, and the 6^16 combination code entry) could potentially be beaten by a single attacker (there’s probably more nuance, we don’t get to see the model of the presumed pin-tumbler lock used, … maybe?):

1. Independently pick each lock, and but not turned enough to begin engaging the mechanism; pick the first and hold it’s just-picked state with string or something similar to allow for the picking of lock #2.

2. Use string to turn the locks in the 2-second window, holding it as required. If one of the locks turns to engage in the opposite direction string could still be used potentially to loop and allow a single attacker to engage both key systems.

3. Depending on design and construction, a lot of radial-dial combination lock systems are susceptible to shim-decoding attacks. The combination code entry system around 4:09 looks interesting. Not sure if this could be attacked in a similar fashion.

A long time ago when I was in school we had to do write a report that was based on information obtained via our congressman. The choices were things like pollution, hunger, homelessness. I suggested nuclear war and wound up being the only person to tackle it. From my congressman I received a packet 250 pages thick with about 98% of the text redacted (blacked out). Of the things that it did say was that in the event of a full scale global thermo-nuclear war the total estimated number of human survivors was about one to two million. Then the numbers would begin to decline further still as fallout poisoned the water, air and wildlife making drinking, eating and even breathing toxic. A truly terrifying notion. We were never responsible enough as a species to harness the power of the atom.

This museum and de-activated missile in its silo were used for filming the booster of Zephram Cochrane's warp ship Phoenix in the movie Star Trek:  First Contact, although the ship shown in space was inaccurate in that it had only one engine bell unlike the two bells which were standard on the Titan II.

The launch procedure as shown is consistent with a number of fictional portrayals of the same. The methods of physical security were never secret, what had to be kept confidential at all costs were the various codes which needed to be verified for a launch to take place.

In point of fact, the launch procedure was publicized to allay fears that a launch could occur by accident, or that one officer could perform an unauthorized, illegal launch.

I find it somewhat interesting that in a doco on uranium (and therefore fission) you dont point out that a thermonuclear weapon is actually a fusion weapon, that a VERY small fission bomb is there only to provide enough energy to start the fusion. So much hype over nuclear bombs being associated with fission reactors, and how fusion will be the way of the clean future, but nobody seemingly ever points out that virtually every nuclear weapon ever deployed was a fusion weapon.
It is also interesting so little is made of why we chose thermal neutron reactors over fast neutron reactors too - its very clear that the fast neutron projects were shut down because they just dont produce material for nuclear weapons, if that hadnt been a concern we would have had dozens of times less waste that was dangerous for hundreds of times shorter time.
It is very sad that thermal neutron tech and nuclear weapons (and some incredibly poor designs) have poisoned public thinking against nuclear technology at a time when we desperately need it. We should be doing all we can now to get fast neutron reactors up and running re-using existing waster to power our transition over long term to renewables. Not only is it the best chance of avoiding a climate disaster, but the only way to make the waste we have safer.

There was also a restriction that one silo couldn't launch without another number of them launching as well. That keeps rogue airmen from launching theirs if they bypass external security or safety measures. If a silo didn't respond to a launch order (including a drill) the command could be notified as well because Soviets could always disable or infiltrate a silo crew but that one non-launch wouldn't mean nobody else could launch. My father worked those silos in the 60s.  He was in the USAF based out of Davis-Monthan in Tucson.  He wasn't a pilot or what they call commander here and I thought there were only 21 or 24 silos in AZ not the 54 mentioned in this article.  His duties were to dispatch out to the sites and test the environmental conditions like heating/cooling and if there were any hazards in the air that would make being down there for periods of time unsafe for the men.  I think it forever changed his perception on the world because he was always the type to be prepared (prepper) and a very avid reader on politics and world affairs.  Seems to have made him a bit paranoid and have less faith in the good of humanity.

Great video! Only thing I noticed was the incorrect shutter speed setting used when filming inside the room with the missile itself. When not shooting at the proper shutter speed you get a flicker or rolling banner effect that becomes apparent only when you watch the video played back. Your shutter speed wasn't the same or a divisible fraction as the 60hz fluorescent lights. Fluorescent forces you to shoot at 1/60 or multiples of it (1/30 1/120 1/240) to avoid the effect or you could always use alternative lighting. This changes depending on the power cycle of the country you're in and when in Europe a lot of the current is 50hz there so you'd have to change your shutter speed to 1/50 or a divisible fraction of it. Keep up the good work!

If you think about it, nuclear weapons are one of the few inventions which have actually saved lives. When used in World War 2, sure they killed thousands of people, but if not for those atomic bombs, millions would have died in an invasion. And ever since their invention, there has never been a world war. The only real risk of having nuclear weapons is the chance that a terrorist could get their hands on one and use it. I don't think any country would ever use a nuclear weapon against another country.

About nuclear weapons i am still a little unsure if they're actually the worse and not the better.

I still think that Little Boy and Fat Man -> Hiroshima and Nagasaki were necessary. I think that the bigger influence had the Soviet declaration of War and the immense pressure they put on the japanese forces in China (Manchuria) and the impending invasion of japanese homeland. As the japanese emperor back in the day was still like a demigod for the people and the military they tried until the very end to bring themselves into a better position to negotiate terms of surrender as the unconditional surrender the U.S.A. had issued included that the removal of their emperor which for japan was hardly acceptable and tried to the very end (unknowing that the soviet union which had not renewed the neutrality pact) actually agreed to enter war against japan)
As they faced the fact that they would probably not get any better conditions they faced an invasion of two forces on their homeland probably leading to a split of the homeland. Additionally the Soviets where for the worse when thinking about the emperor.
(the bombs might have had a role but conventional bombardments would've had the same effects in fact conventional / incinerating bombardment probably killed far more japanese civilians than both bombs together)
And i know i am going to get a lot of controversy for that :-)

But on a bigger scale these weapons might actually have brought more stability to the world as nobody ever wanted to use them but everybody feared them it might have lead to a stronger motivation to keep conflicts to a minimum with those states and their allies.
On this train of thought the cruel fate of the residents of Hiroshima and Nagasaki might actually have had a strong effect on the people pulling the strings and so preventing those weapons from being used ever again. People like Stanislav Petrov or Vasili Arkhipov might not have been where they were when it counted and we would've had a nuclear WW III

On the other hand this kind of weapon is like the Pandora's box placed under the sword of Damocles. I think our world would look quite different today without them and i am, as i wrote before, not sure if the world today would be better without them.

Off-topic rant about the Norwegian channel that's airing this:

Although "NRK" sounds like "anarchy", it's really an acronym for "Norsk RiksKringkasting", or "Norwegian Kingdom Broadcast". It's not a channel for people who want to end the government, but in fact is owned by the government, and funded by sending everyone who owns a TV set a yearly bill for the ability to watch the channel, even though it's an open broadcast and not subscription based. In return the channel does not show commercials, and doesn't have to take on sponsorships. Hence it is free from those biases.

Although having an unbiased media outlet is a good thing, their source of income is becoming more and more of a problem. As most media is so readily available online these days, and at the consumer's leisure instead of a set schedule, the annual NRK license fee feels more like a robbery than support for a good cause. Maybe even more so for younger generations who don't care as much for their programming, which mainly consists of news, Norwegian sports, and depressing English drama series like Heartbeat.

The fee this year is approximately 336 US dollars, and as a person who doesn't watch the channel, I'd rather not pay it. How do people in other countries feel about this?

Stanislav Petrov is a man who prevented a nuclear war. From Wikipedia: on September 26, 1983, he was the duty officer at the command center for the Oko nuclear early-warning system when the system reported that a missile was being launched from the United States. Petrov judged the report to be a false alarm, and his decision is credited with having prevented an erroneous retaliatory nuclear attack on the United States and its NATO allies that could have resulted in large-scale nuclear war. Investigation later confirmed that the satellite warning system had indeed malfunctioned.
